member.name: T:Weaver.AssetListBase
member.summary: A containing a list which is automatically populated with all assets of a given type in a specific folder. Gathering takes place in the Unity Editor so the list can be loaded efficiently at runtime and the target assets do not need to be in a Resources folder.
member.remarks: Unfortunately, Editor-Only fields (such as the target and flag) can't be declared in a pre-compiled assembly or generic type. This complicates the structure of Weaver's source code since needs to be inside Weaver.dll to integrate with other systems while the other classes (AssetList, AssetList<T>, LazyAssetList<T>, and MetaAssetList<TAsset, TMeta>) need to be out in the Unity project for Unity to compile them itself.

member.summary:
[Editor-Only] After you save the scene object `obj` as an asset file and load it as `asset`, this method goes through all the serialized fields which weren't saved and adds them as sub-assets. Returns true if any sub-assets were saved.
For example, creating a procedural , assigning it to a , and saving the object as a prefab would not save the mesh anywhere unless you call this method or .

[Editor-Only, Internal] In Edit Mode we inject everything using an [].
In Play Mode we inject everything using [] so it can be applied before the scene is loaded.
During the build process we generate a procedural script and attach it to an object in the first scene so that it can inject everything efficiently on startup.

Called automatically by Unity when entering Play Mode. Executes all s to apply their values to their attributed members.
This would normally be called on startup in a runtime build as well, but runtime initialisation is handled by the procedural .

member.name: M:Weaver.Editor.WeaverSettingsBase.ForceReSerialize
member.summary: When the type of an is changed Unity needs to serialize all references to it and then deserialize them with the new type. Unfortunately it the type change isn't an intentional feature of the engine so it doesn't have a clean way to do so. This method modifies a for a dummy field to force Unity to recognise that the data has changed. This only works for references to the list in question inside itself; unfortunately, other references will still hold their reference to the list object with the old type until assemblies are reloaded.

member.name: T:Weaver.AnimationReferenceAttribute
member.summary:
Marks a or field to show a popup menu in the inspector which lets you select an animation value name or hash respectively. Values include both states and parameters.
WARNING: selecting a value using this attribute does not link the field to that state or parameter. Renaming the state or parameter will NOT automatically update the value of the attributed field.
If you're interested in an animation system which avoids the need for these weak unsafe references entirely, you should check out Animancer.

member.name: M:Weaver.CSharp.GetNameCS(System.Type,Weaver.CSharp.NameVerbosity)
member.summary: Returns the name of a `type` as it would appear in C# code. Results are cached.
member.example:
typeof(List<float>).FullName would give: System.Collections.Generic.List`1[[System.Single, mscorlib, Version=2.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089]] This method would instead return a different result depending on the specified `verbosity`:
would return "List<float>".
is like but also includes nested types.
would return "System.Collections.Generic.List<float>".
would return "global::System.Collections.Generic.List<float>".

Creates a that creates new items by instantiating a specified . The objects will not be destroyed by scene loading.
In the Unity Editor the instantiated objects will be grouped under a common parent to keep the hierarchy view tidy, but this step is skipped in runtime builds for efficiency.
